items.title: SVG with clipPath forces stroked border
items.body:
Thanks for publishing this library, it's very helpful for including matplotlib plots in PDF reports.

I've run into trouble when my SVG needs to be clipped to its bounding rectangle. I'd like to just clip it, but it also draws the the bounding rectangle.

Here's a small example of what I'm trying to do. The circle is drawn half outside the top boundary of the SVG, so I want to see a semicircle.

    import svgwrite
    from io import BytesIO
    
    from reportlab.platypus import SimpleDocTemplate
    from svglib.svglib import svg2rlg
    
    
    def go():
        doc = SimpleDocTemplate("example.pdf")
        story = []
        svg_drawing = svgwrite.Drawing(size=("400px", "200px"))
        clip_path = svg_drawing.defs.add(svg_drawing.clipPath(id='border_clip'))
        clip_path.add(svg_drawing.rect(size=(400, 200), fill='red', stroke='blue'))
        svg_drawing.add(svg_drawing.circle((200, 0),
                                           60,
                                           clip_path='url(#border_clip)'))
        svg_text = svg_drawing.tostring()
        svg_bytes = svg_text.encode()
        pdf_drawing = svg2rlg(BytesIO(svg_bytes))
    
        story.append(pdf_drawing)
        doc.build(story)
    
    
    go()

The PDF looks like this:

![Screenshot from 2020-03-28 14-31-38](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1639148/77834291-ee4a3200-7100-11ea-8b2a-87b7f35600d6.png)

Here's what I want the PDF to look like, without drawing the bounding rectangle:

![Screenshot from 2020-03-28 14-48-16](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1639148/77834610-3a967180-7103-11ea-81c0-bf1febb98ef3.png)

### Analysis
I did some investigation, and the problem appears to be that [`Canvas.clipPath()`] is receiving `stroke=1`. That tells it to stroke the clip path. It's hard for me to tell exactly how that stroke value is decided, but it seems to be left as the default when calling [`convertRect()`] on the rectangle in the clipping path. Perhaps it should copy the stroke from the rectangle instead of using the default. As you can see in my snippet, I set the stroke, but it was ignored.

### Workaround
It's ugly, but I worked around this by monkeypatching `Canvas.clipPath()`. That just changes it from always drawing the clip path to never drawing it. Some users might want to choose the stroke for each clip path.

Here's my example with the monkeypatch. It produces the second PDF, above.

    import svgwrite
    from io import BytesIO
    from reportlab.pdfgen.canvas import Canvas
    
    from reportlab.platypus import SimpleDocTemplate
    from svglib.svglib import svg2rlg
    
    original_clip_path = Canvas.clipPath
    
    
    # noinspection PyUnusedLocal,PyPep8Naming
    def patched_clip_path(canvas,
                          aPath,
                          stroke=1,
                          fill=0,
                          fillMode=None):
        stroke = 0
        # noinspection PyArgumentList
        return original_clip_path(canvas, aPath, stroke, fill, fillMode)
    
    
    def go():
        Canvas.clipPath = patched_clip_path
        doc = SimpleDocTemplate("example.pdf")
        story = []
        svg_drawing = svgwrite.Drawing(size=("400px", "200px"))
        clip_path = svg_drawing.defs.add(svg_drawing.clipPath(id='border_clip'))
        clip_path.add(svg_drawing.rect(size=(400, 200), fill='red', stroke='blue'))
        svg_drawing.add(svg_drawing.circle((200, 0),
                                           60,
                                           clip_path='url(#border_clip)'))
        svg_text = svg_drawing.tostring()
        svg_bytes = svg_text.encode()
        pdf_drawing = svg2rlg(BytesIO(svg_bytes))
    
        story.append(pdf_drawing)
        doc.build(story)
    
    
    go()

I'm using these versions:

* svglib 1.0.0
* reportlab 3.5.42
* Python 3.8.2
* Ubuntu 18.04

[`convertRect()`]: https://github.com/deeplook/svglib/blob/v1.0.0/svglib/svglib.py#L981-L985
[`Canvas.clipPath()`]: https://github.com/MrBitBucket/reportlab-mirror/blob/0191da4e0c8a1421517f385548dcfca5e3a2bf63/src/reportlab/pdfgen/canvas.py#L1767

items.title: throwing ValueError for SVG 1.2 tiny files
items.body:
Hello, 

I've got a question. When I call svg2rlg for a svg 1.2 file (the full tag is \<svg width="595.44" height="841.68" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:_xmlns="xmlns" _xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny" style="background-color:#fff"\>) I yield the following exception: 

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "C:\path\to\svglib.py", line 1422, in svg2rlg
    drawing = svgRenderer.render(svg_root)
  File "C:\path\to\svglib.py", line 580, in render
    main_group = self.renderSvg(node, outermost=True)
  File "C:\path\to\svglib.py", line 834, in renderSvg
    self.renderNode(child, group)
  File "C:\path\to\svglib.py", line 643, in renderNode
    item = self.shape_converter.convertShape(name, n, clipping)
  File "C:\path\to\svglib.py", line 945, in convertShape
    shape = getattr(self, method_name)(node)
  File "C:\path\to\svglib.py", line 1257, in convertPath
    rx, ry, phi, fA, fS, x2, y2 = nums
ValueError: not enough values to unpack (expected 7, got 3)

Apparently the elliptical arc in this older version contains only 3 numbers. Catching this exception in the module, I found, that there are also elliptical arcs with different amount of numbers given (starting from 1 to 6, but never 7). Is there any support or workaround for such 'broken' files? Many thanks in advance!

items.title: reportLab svg2rlg bug when handling clip-paths
items.body:
It appears that clip-paths are ignored when importing SVG files into reportLab PDF with svg2rlg.

If an SVG file has a graphics object with a clip-path assigned (this is typical for matplotlib graphics where the plot extends outside an axis), then the SVG file will not render properly when importing into a reportLab PDF via svg2rlg.

The SVG file looks correct in AI or Explorer, so the problem appears to be with svg2rlg.

The problems appears to be that svglib parses the SVG XML tree assuming that clip-paths will be present in the tree before they are used, which is not the case for matplotlib SVG exports (clip-paths are at the bottom of the XML tree).

The easiest way I found around this (seems to be working) is just to run the renderNode loop twice in renderSvg: the first time on a throw away group, the second time with the actual group instance.

The first pass will build the Group instance self.definitions dict, which will then be fully populated and available the second pass.

```
def renderSvg(self, node, outermost=False):
    _saved_preserve_space = self.shape_converter.preserve_space
    self.shape_converter.preserve_space = node.getAttribute("{%s}space" % XML_NS) == 'preserve'

    group_throwaway = Group()
    for child in node.getchildren():
        self.renderNode(child, group_throwaway)

    group = Group()
    for child in node.getchildren():
        self.renderNode(child, group)
```

items.body:

Code:
```
saved_image_path = 'test_png.png'

            f.write(image)
drawing = svg2rlg(image_path)

]>

items.title: Graph's data plotted out of limits
items.body:
Dear all,

Thank you for this package. When trying to convert my with python created .svg files to a .pdf file, the data is plotted also outside the axes, meaning outside the limits I set (compare figure2.svg to figure3.pdf). How can I get rid of this?

Please find a working example below. Thank you for any input and/or help with this issue!
All the best,
Gabi

[figures.zip](https://github.com/deeplook/svglib/files/4140769/figures.zip)

`import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import svgutils.compose as sc
from IPython.display import SVG
from pylab import rcParams
rcParams['figure.figsize'] = 4 , 3

# some 'data'
x = np.linspace(0,10,100)
y1 = np.exp(x)
y2 = 2*np.exp(x)**2

# the figure
fig0 = plt.figure(0)
fig0.subplots_adjust(left=0.15, bottom=0.15, right=0.95, top=0.95)
ax = fig0.add_subplot(111)
ax.grid(True, lw = 0.5, ls = '--', c = '.5') # adds a grid
ax.set_xlabel(r'xlabel')
ax.set_ylabel(r'ylabel')
ax.ticklabel_format(style='sci', axis ='y', scilimits=(0,0) , useMathText=True) # x and y axis format
ax.set_yscale('log')  # plot y axis as a log scale
ax.set_ylim(0,10000)
ax.plot(x, y1, label='Mode 1')
ax.plot(x, y2, label='Mode 2')
ax.legend(loc='upper right')
plt.show()

# save the figure as svg
fig0.savefig('figure1.svg', transparent=True, bbox_inches='tight')

# assemble figure with any other svg file
sc.Figure("286.578", "221.355",
    sc.Panel(sc.SVG("figure1.svg")),
    sc.Panel(sc.SVG("2-methynaphthalene.svg").scale(0.5).move(40,70))
    ).save("figure2.svg")
SVG('figure2.svg')

# now convert to pdf
from svglib.svglib import svg2rlg
from reportlab.graphics import renderPDF

drawing = svg2rlg("figure2.svg")
renderPDF.drawToFile(drawing, "figure3.pdf")`

items.title: Upgrading from SVGLIB 0.8.1 to 0.9.2 Breaks - SVG Images Now Appear in Black and White
items.body:
(I first posted this issue last year, but decided not to upgrade until now.)

I have been using SVGLIB 0.8.1 for a few years now to incorporate existing color SVG chart images (created in R) into a PDF file. It has worked great.

When I try to upgrade to the latest SVGLIB 0.9.2, on a clean Windows machine with Python 3.6.1, my imported SVG images (which are fine themselves) now appear in black and white once imported in the PDF file.

I also get this error when executing SVGLIB commands:

Unable to find a suitable font for 'font-family:Nimbus Sans L'

I really would like to upgrade SVGLIB. What am I doing wrong here?

Simply upgrading to SVGLIB 0.9.2 causes the process of importing SVG images into PDFs to break. Downgrading back to 0.8.1 returns everything to normal.


    from svglib.svglib import svg2rlg
    my_canvas = canvas.Canvas(strLinuxMultiserverReportTemporaryFilename)
    my_canvas.setPageSize((11.5*inch, 40*inch))
    drawing = svg2rlg(image_path)

    intHeaderIndex = 2850
    my_canvas.drawString(350, intHeaderIndex, 'System Performance Report')

    my_canvas.save()

I expect my nice color SVG files to be imported into the PDF file by SVGLIB and stay in color.

Any help is greatly appreciated.

Lou

items.title: SVG colors no supported?
items.body:
It seems that svglib does not support SVG colors, or at least note the svg2rlg method.

For instance, when processing an SVG file generated by GraphViz:
```
In [1]: from svglib.svglib import svg2rlg
In [2]: drawing = svg2rlg('dot_graph.svg')
Can't handle color: transparent
Can't handle color: slategrey
```
I'm looking forward for a release that support SVG color keywords (https://www.w3.org/TR/2013/WD-SVG2-20130409/single-page.html#types-ColorKeywords).

items.title: Regression in viewbox size
items.body:
Commit 82860fa54f8a2b added a regression in master when a viewbox contains percentage height/width values (most files in the SVG Tiny test suite are affected).

This is due to the fact that svglib now takes viewbox width and height into account (which is a good thing), however master is currently not handling percentage values. To fix that, #186 is adding percentage value support. @deeplook Are you ok to merge that PR?

FYI, the test which currently fails:
```
diff --git a/tests/test_basic.py b/tests/test_basic.py
index 1d293c4..9fed4bb 100755
--- a/tests/test_basic.py
+++ b/tests/test_basic.py
@@ -651,6 +651,19 @@ class TestViewBox(object):
         # Main group coordinates are translated to match the viewBox origin
         assert drawing.contents[0].transform == (1, 0, 0, -1, 60.0, 40.0)
 
+    def test_percent_width_height(self):
+        drawing = svglib.svg2rlg(io.StringIO(textwrap.dedent(u'''\
+            <?xml version="1.0"?>

+                 width="100%" height="100%"
+                 viewBox="0 0 480 360">

+                </g>

+        assert (drawing.width, drawing.height) == (480, 360)
+
 
 class TestEmbedded(object):
     def test_svg_in_svg(self):

items.title: passing file-like object to svg2rlg
items.body:
I want to use `svg2rlg` with `io.BytesIO`, but it wants a path to a file, and not a file-like object, so I need to create a `tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile`, copy the `BytesIO` content there, and then `svg2rlg` with that temporary file's name. This is a bit inconvenient, and can be slow with large files. Ideally `svg2rlg` could also take a file-like object instead of a path.

Currently `svg2rlg` has `svgz` code that creates an `svg` file in the same directory as where the `svgz` file is. That must be changed to implement this because `BytesIO` objects don't even have a directory where they are, but I think that using a temporary file or `BytesIO` would be better anyway.

Whenever I try to load an svg file, e.g. "drawing = svg2rlg('file.svg')" or running svg2pdf, I get the following error:

    NameError: name 'xrange' is not defined

which, as far as I know, is due to running Python 2 code in Python 3.

I run python 3.6 and installed svglib with pip, so why does this happen?

Thanks!

R.

items.title: Get feedback about moving to GitLab
items.body: I'm experimenting with a new project on GitLab, and if successful, might think about moving this project there, maybe in 2019. GitLab provides many additional features over GitHub, including integrated CI (supporting Unix, Windows, macOS). The community is surely smaller than GitHub's, but constantly growing and attracting ever more projects to move from GitHub especially since it was taken over by Microsoft. It also received $100M of D series investment money very recently. Any opinions?

items.title: Make a new release 0.9.0, RSN
items.body: There have been many requests for a new release of svglib on PyPI, which I have procrastinated for way too long (my sincerest apologies!). I've collected some thoughts in https://github.com/deeplook/svglib/wiki/Release-Process, but in the end it will likely happen rather by mimicking a few techniques I found to be successfully used when instantiating projects with https://github.com/audreyr/cookiecutter/ using a template like https://github.com/audreyr/cookiecutter-pypackage which I've used for something different, before. It relies on a couple of tools like `bumpversion` (not really maintained anymore) and `twine`, but using anything else will be better than what there is now (not much).

items.title: Issue with nested svg tags, producing incorrect image.
items.body:
using svglib-1.8.1, Python 3.6.2 :: Anaconda custom (32-bit)
installed using pip

I am working with svg files where I need to used nested svg tag to establish local coordinate reference frames.  The library does not produce the appropriate output with nested tags.  I reduced the examples to a very minimal level.

_Unfortunately the issue editor does not support attaching SVG or python files so I will include below._

File 1:  Nested SVG Example
`<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
<svg height="520" version="1.1" width="600">
    <defs>
    <svg height="30" width="300" x="0" y="0">
        <defs />
        <text x="0" y="15" fill="black">Test text</text>
    </svg>
</svg>`
Blank image file:  
![file 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38887387/39877685-915e9fde-5444-11e8-8dd0-4423988ae845.png)
End of image

File 2: Non Nest Example:
`<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
<svg height="30" width="300" x="0" y="0">
    <defs />
    <text x="0" y="15" fill="black">Test text</text>
</svg>`
Image with text:
![file 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38887387/39877695-96a7bc28-5444-11e8-8daa-b33eae783dc7.png)

The python code is pretty much straight from documention:

`"""Convert svg to png"""
from svglib.svglib import svg2rlg
from reportlab.graphics import renderPM, renderPDF

drawing = svg2rlg("file.svg")
renderPM.drawToFile(drawing, "file.png", fmt="PNG")
`
Is there something I need to do either within my code or the svg file to get this to work?

items.title: When using viewBox attribute, canvas size is not scaled to width and height of svg attribute
items.body:
When trying to convert the following svg to png

```
from svglib.svglib import svg2rlg
from reportlab.graphics import renderPDF, renderPM

svgtemplate="""
<svg   width="1250" height="1250"  viewBox="-40 -40 80 80">
<rect width="30" height="30" style="fill:red" />
</svg>
"""
def png(svg,pngfilename):
    text_file = open("template.svg", "w")
    text_file.write(svg)
    text_file.close()
    drawing = svg2rlg("template.svg")
    renderPM.drawToFile(drawing, pngfilename)

png(svgtemplate,'Test_viewBox.png')
```

I receive a png that is only 80px x 80px.
It should be 1250 x 1250 and the rect should be scaled accordingly.

(svglib 0.8.1 python 3.6.4 Windows 7)

items.body:
I've got a simple matplotlib graph with one red and one green marker. Saving the figure as svg it renders correctly (attached graph.svg). When I draw the same graph on a reportlab Canvas and save it the markers are now filled with black (attached document.pdf).

Any idea on what is causing this behaviour? This is on Python 2.7, Ubuntu 14.04 running with the latest versions of reportlab and svglib . Script and requirements.txt to reproduce are attached.
 
Thanks

Attachments are in the zip below
[svgbug.zip](https://github.com/deeplook/svglib/files/1831784/svgbug.zip)

items.title: Support rgba-type colors
items.body: Only rgb(...) colors are supported for now. Opacity should be set by the a value.

items.title: Generated PDF is all black
items.body:
Hi,

I am using pygal to generate a SVG file which displays just fine in my browser. But when I convert it to any other format (PDF, jpg, png) using svglib, all I am getting is a picture completely black.

I am on OSX, do I need any additional package/library installed?

Thanks

items.title: Different PDF output between runs with hash randomization enabled
items.body:
Hi!

We have regression tests that use `svglib` to embed SVG files into PDF reports. Those tests work by generating a PDF file and saving it as the "expected" output in a designated directory the first time they execute. The generated PDF files are manually examined and if they are correct, they are committed to Git so future runs now generate a new PDF file and compare it with the "expected" output: if they differ then the test fails.

Those tests fail in Python 3.5, because every execution of the test suite produces a different PDF file. The cause seems to be hash randomization which is enabled by default in Python 3: the same tests also fail on Python 2.7 if we set the `PYTHONHASHSEED` environment variable to `random`. Also, the same tests produce the same PDF file on Python 3.5 if `PYTHONHASHSEED` is set to the same value (`1` for example).

It seems the conversion process is dependent on order of iterations over dicts/sets somehow.

I was wondering if this is a known issue (I couldn't find anything on the tracker) and if there might be a workaround.

Any advice would be greatly appreciated!

----

Reproducible example:

```python
import os
from reportlab.graphics import renderPDF
from svglib import svglib

def test_svg_to_pdf():
    pdf_image = svglib.svg2rlg('image.svg')
    i = 1
    while True:
        filename = 'file{0}.pdf'.format(i)
        if not os.path.isfile(filename):
            break
        i += 1
    renderPDF.drawToFile(pdf_image, filename)
```

Running this test twice will generate `file1.pdf` and `file2.pdf`. Here's the diff with hash randomization turned on and off:

**Hash optimization OFF**

```diff

--- file2.pdf   Tue Dec  5 16:46:51 2017
***************
*** 54,60 ****
  % 'R6': class PDFInfo
  6 0 obj

!  /CreationDate (D:20171205164649+03'00')
   /Creator (ReportLab PDF Library - www.reportlab.com)
   /Keywords ()
   /Producer (ReportLab PDF Library - www.reportlab.com)
--- 54,60 ----
  % 'R6': class PDFInfo
  6 0 obj
  << /Author (anonymous)
!  /CreationDate (D:20171205164651+03'00')
   /Creator (ReportLab PDF Library - www.reportlab.com)
   /Keywords ()
   /Producer (ReportLab PDF Library - www.reportlab.com)
***************
*** 97,103 ****
  trailer
  << /ID
   % ReportLab generated PDF document -- digest (http://www.reportlab.com)
!  [(\236!\035*7\326\241\244\317\031\313\250\215\241\375\324) (\236!\035*7\326\241\244\317\031\313\250\215\241\375\324)]

   /Info 6 0 R
   /Root 5 0 R
--- 97,103 ----
  trailer
  << /ID

!  [(\267{\227\035\202\242\247|9\326`\372\002\245\312\303) (\267{\227\035\202\242\247|9\326`\372\002\245\312\303)]

   /Info 6 0 R
   /Root 5 0 R
```

The files differ in those two lines every run because they are the time-stamp and the hash digest of the document. In our test suite we ignore differences in those two lines.

items.title: Contact owners of stale forks of svglib
items.body:
There seem to be some stale forks of `svglib` on GitHub which were made a long time ago and which don't reflect the many changes that were added with version 0.8.1. I'm getting some requests from people confused by those, and maybe this can be changed by contacting those who have made the forks... 

Here's a very preliminary list:

- https://github.com/DataMarket/svglib
- https://github.com/sweh/svglib

To be continued...

items.title: Fix badges for Travis and AppVeyor CI
Running svg2rlg second time returns None.
items.body:
I have to draw an image on every page of a PDF file. For that I have a function that does something like this:
```
def draw_logo(file_path):
      rlg = svg2rlg(file_path)
      # Draw on PDF. This part doesn't matter...
```
And for every page I call the function draw_logo. It draws the image on the first page, but when the function is called second time(for second page) svg2rlg returns None. Yet I have found a way to bypass this case, I still think things shouldn't work so.

items.title: Embedded PNG images don't show up?
items.body:
I get a "Adding box instead of image." warning for each embedded PNG image. The output PDF has no images. Any suggestions?

Here's the stanza for the embedded PNG images: 

`<image xlink:href="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAA.../>`

And the code:

```
from svglib.svglib import svg2rlg
from reportlab.graphics import renderPDF, renderPM

drawing = svg2rlg("input.svg")
renderPDF.drawToFile(drawing, "output.pdf")
```

items.title: Think about using this package to render GeoJSON files
items.body: Converting GeoJSON into something visual is still kind of an unnecessarily complicated issue. Using sites like geojson.io or GitHub gists makes this easier, but creating something quickly local seems to be overly complex, often  involving some node.js tools. It might be interesting to come up with a simple solution using `svglib` to convert them into SVG and from there to PDF. Any practical help would be highly welcome.

items.body:
I installed svglib today with pip.

The install didn't finish before something timed out.

I disabled test cases, installs and works fine.     It wasn't use CPU - maybe a download hung or something.

I couldn't work out why, I'll have a look later.

items.title: Choose image dimensions when calling renderPM.drawToFile
items.body: Is there any way to choose the dimensions of the image that is saved by calling `renderPM.drawToFile` or by any other method?

items.title: font-family not handled properly?
items.body:
The example document uses the fonts "Dingbats", "Verdana", "serif", "Times-Roman" and "Helvetica". In the generated PDF I can only find "/Times-Roman" (may be a correct substitute for "serif") and "Helvetica".

1. "serif" seems to be handle properly, see second line ("Zeile 3")
2. "Times-Roman" and "Helvetica seem to be handled properly, see second text-block: Times (green) renders differently than Helvetica (black).
3. "Dingbats" is ignored, see fist line (blue).
4. "Verdana" is ignored, see last block: The text using Helvetica (black) is printed at the same position as the second one using Verdana (red). While Verdana is different from Helvetica, the text is rendering the same, as you can see.

``` xml
<?xml version="1.0" standalone="no"?>
<svg width="210mm" height="297mm"
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" version="2">
<text x="5cm" y="10cm" xml:space="preserve"
      font-family="Dingbats" font-size="32" fill="blue"><tspan/>
<tspan>Hello, out </tspan>
<tspan font-weight="bold" fill="red">not</tspan><tspan> there!</tspan>
<tspan font-family="serif" x="5cm" dy="32">Zeile 3 iIlL</tspan>
  </text>

<text x="5cm" y="13cm"
      font-family="Times-Roman" font-size="32" fill="lightgreen">
2. Hello, out not there!</text>
<text x="5cm" y="13cm"
      font-family="Helvetica" font-size="32">
3. Hello, out not there!</text>

<text x="5cm" y="14.5cm"
      font-family="Verdana" font-size="32" fill="red">
4. Hello, out not there!</text>
<text x="5cm" y="14.5cm"
      font-family="Helvetica" font-size="32">
5. Hello, out not there!</text>

</svg>
```

![grafik](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/784161/26762393/a91174ee-4941-11e7-9227-818884f44761.png)

items.title: Remaining little flag artefacts
items.body: Three flags in `samples/wikipedia/flags` show minor but clearly visible artefacts with paths and/or clipping: `Kyrgyzstan.svg`, `Slovenia.svg` and `The_republic_of_china.svg`.

items.title: "y" in "tspan" interpreted as relative coordinate?
items.body:
I tried to convert an SVG that contains the following text node, which contains a `y` key both in the `text` tag and in the `tspan` code:

```svg
  <text
     id="text125"
     data-bb="18"
     style="font-family: "Open Sans", verdana, arial, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; fill: rgb(68, 68, 68); fill-opacity: 1; visibility: inherit; white-space: pre;"
     transform="translate(24.66,0)"
     y="234"  // y is defined here...
     x="0"
     text-anchor="middle">
    <tspan
       id="tspan121"
       y="234"  // ... and here again
       x="0"
       dy="0em"
       class="line">Oct 6</tspan>
    <tspan
       id="tspan123"
       y="234"
       x="0"
       dy="1.3em"
       class="line">2013</tspan>
  </text>
```

This node disappears off the page when converting it using `svg2pdf`, presumably because in https://github.com/deeplook/svglib/blob/master/svglib/svglib.py#L720, the y coordinates are added. If I understand correctly, the inner `y` keyword should be interpreted as an absolute coordinate though, so the outer `y` should be ignored in this case.


[plot.svg.txt](https://github.com/deeplook/svglib/files/907594/plot.svg.txt)

items.title: svg would not parse
Windows support
items.body:
I noted the "pure python" and "no windows support" and wondered why.

On Windows, I did  pip install svglib  and it wasn't blocked, and also installed lxml.

Didn't find any tests after the install, which the readme had sort of hinted might be installed that way, but wouldn't be the second way...

Downloaded the whole shebang as a ZIP from github, which doesn't include the wikipedia samples, I guess, but there were some in "misc".  Firefox complained about some of them having syntax errors, and some not having style, so just displayed the XML tree.  GNU Emacs on Windows actually showed the graphic form of the .svg which surprised me, I hadn't discovered that feature of Emacs before, but it worked well enough, except didn't scale the images to fit the window, so had to maximize the window to see some of them in full.

Didn't find pyTest, so did a loop over *.svg to run svg2pdf.py (copy of svg2pdf so Windows Python launcher would be happy with it) and while there were some messages on the screen, it seems that .pdf files were generated, and they displayed fine (within the limits of my understanding of what "fine" should look like, based on what I could see in emacs, and cursory visual inspection) except for the airbus.pdf showed up with the fuselage all filled with black. The log of messages appears at the end.

It seems Firefox might not like the ones that don't start with <svg> with full DTD specified, which might be reasonable, but there were a couple, one of which was airbus, that gave a syntax error (pasted below). Not sure if the error is for the <g> or the prior <metadata>, or the combination.

So I never heard of svglib until the recent "revival" messages on reportlab-users mailing list, so I clearly don't know what I am doing, or how to interpret the errors, and I'm pretty much a novice with SVG, but trying to learn for a project, so I can't presently say much more about all this. But svg2pdf looks like it could be useful for my Windows-based project, if it goes in certain directions... and it seems that a fair bit of the code works fairly well on Windows...


So why isn't there Windows support?  :)

items.title: Paths are closed which shouldn't be
items.body:
I think there might be an issue with closing paths which also shows in a series of flag examples, e.g. that of Bhutan. I've condensed the following minimal example from `tests/samples/wikipedia/symbols/Flower-of-Life-small.svg`:

```svg
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<svg
	xmlns:svg="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
	xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
	width="304"
	height="304"
	id="svg2"
	version="1.0">
	<g
		id="idLayerDrawing"
		style="display:inline"
		transform="translate(-348,-348)">
		<path
			style="opacity:1;fill:none;fill-opacity:1;fill-rule:nonzero;stroke:#000000;stroke-width:1;stroke-linecap:butt;stroke-linejoin:miter;stroke-miterlimit:4;stroke-opacity:1;visibility:visible;display:inline;overflow:visible;enable-background:accumulate"
			id="path4481"
			d="M 543.30127,375 A 50,50 0 0 1 500,400"
			transform="translate(-43.30127,-25)"
			/>
	</g>
</svg>
```

Clearly, there is no `z` in the path here, but for some reason this seems to be ok. Maybe it's the `fill-rule:nonzero` style... (well, apparently not).

items.title: Use lxml instead of minidom to parse SVG files
items.body:
If we want to support CSS style sheets, it seems that using cssselect is a must.
https://pythonhosted.org/cssselect/
But to take advantage of it, we need an XML library which supports Xpath expressions. So I suggest to replace minidom usage by lxml. Is that reasonable?

items.title: Spread the news about the next release on StackOverflow
items.body: There are some threads about `svglib` there, see http://stackoverflow.com/search?q=svglib which could benefit from a brief update about the next release (after making the release).

items.title: Find a Python SVG logo to bundle with the included tests
items.body: Those official ones are using one gradient for blue and yellow each which means they will currently not be rendered: https://www.python.org/community/logos/ So one without gradients would be nice.

items.title: Extend svg2pdf to generate other formats
items.body: This should be easy given that there are other ReportLab renderers, like `renderPM` for bitmaps and `renderPS` for Postscript. And with `renderSVG` one could also do round-trip testing. The most difficult question then might be which name to choose for this extended tool instead of `svg2pdf`?

items.title: AttrConverterTestCase failure on Python 2
items.body: On Python 2, io.StringIO needs a unicode string. @deeplook, do you want to support Python 3.2? We could add the `u""` prefix before the string, but Python 3.2 doesn't support it (it was readded in 3.3).
